articles.headline: Ex-Rival Edwards Throws His Support to Obama
articles.snippet: The endorsement could offer Senator Barack Obama help in his efforts to win over working-class white voters.
articles.abstract: The endorsement could offer Senator Barack Obama help in his efforts to win over working-class white voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.  John Edwards gave his long-awaited endorsement to Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday, bolstering Mr. Obama’s efforts to rally the Democratic Party around his candidacy and offering potential help in his efforts to win over working class white voters in the general election.

articles.headline: Chinese Soldiers Rush to Bolster Weakened Dams
articles.snippet: The Chinese government said that the earthquake had damaged nearly 400 dams, and the death toll estimate rose to 15,000.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government said that the earthquake had damaged nearly 400 dams, and the death toll estimate rose to 15,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China  China mobilized 30,000 additional soldiers to the earthquake-shattered expanses of the nation’s southwestern regions on Wednesday  not just to help victims, but also to shore up weakened dams and other elements of the infrastructure whose failure could compound the disaster.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Collateral Foreclosure Damage for Condo Owners
articles.snippet: As foreclosures mount and contributions to building associations shrink, condo owners find themselves nagging each other to pay their assessments and haggling over chores.
articles.abstract: As foreclosures mount and contributions to building associations shrink, condo owners find themselves nagging each other to pay their assessments and haggling over chores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barbara Sanz has never missed a mortgage payment, but the plunge in real estate is punishing condominium owners like her anyway.

articles.headline: Republican Election Losses Stir Fall Fears
articles.snippet: After three losses in special Congressional races, some senior Republicans urged their party’s candidates to distance themselves from President Bush.
articles.abstract: After three losses in special Congressional races, some senior Republicans urged their party’s candidates to distance themselves from President Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Republican defeat in a special Congressional contest in Mississippi sent waves of apprehension across an already troubled party Wednesday, with some senior Republicans urging Congressional candidates to distance themselves from President Bush to head off what could be heavy losses in the fall.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: G.E. May Sell Appliance Division
articles.snippet: The announcement comes as G.E.’s chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, tries to fix the troubled conglomerate, which has been hit hard by the slumping economy.
articles.abstract: The announcement comes as G.E.’s chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, tries to fix the troubled conglomerate, which has been hit hard by the slumping economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric is planning to sell its appliance division, one of the oldest businesses in the conglomerate’s 120-year history, people briefed on the proposal said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Merrill Tries to Temper the Pollyannas in Its Ranks
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch unveiled a new system for rating stocks that suggests Wall Street finally may be mustering up its courage to say “sell” more often.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch unveiled a new system for rating stocks that suggests Wall Street finally may be mustering up its courage to say “sell” more often.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes Wall Street seems a bit like the make-believe Lake Wobegon: Most stocks are above average, and it is always a good time to buy.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Tiny Bodies in a Morgue, and Grief in China
articles.snippet: Many victims of the quake are children in a country where most families are allowed to have only one.
articles.abstract: Many victims of the quake are children in a country where most families are allowed to have only one.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUYUAN, China  The bodies are everywhere. Some are zipped inside white vinyl bags and strewn on the floor. Others have been covered in a favorite blanket or dressed in new clothes. There are so many bodies that undertakers want to cremate them in groups. They are all children.

articles.headline: A Bean Bag That Delivers Web Widgets
articles.snippet: Set a Chumby on your bedside table and watch the widgets go by.
articles.abstract: Set a Chumby on your bedside table and watch the widgets go by.
articles.lead_paragraph: O.K., first of all, what’s up with the name Chumby?

articles.headline: Judge Says Countrywide Officers Must Face Suit by Shareholders
articles.snippet: Directors and officers of Countrywide, the beleaguered mortgage lender, will have to answer shareholder accusations of insider trading and a failure to monitor lending practices.
articles.abstract: Directors and officers of Countrywide, the beleaguered mortgage lender, will have to answer shareholder accusations of insider trading and a failure to monitor lending practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Directors and officers of Countrywide Financial, the beleaguered mortgage lender, must answer shareholder accusations of insider trading and an overall failure to monitor lending practices that led to the company’s collapse, a federal judge in California has ruled.
